nodes.text: Conservation of money in an ensemble of economic agents implies a statistical equilibrium described by statistical physics that explains observed money and income distributions, while departures from conservation via state or banking actions and debt dynamics produce instabilities and inequality

If a monetary variable is conserved locally in transactions, and microscopic transaction rules satisfy time-reversal symmetry or are additive, the stationary probability distribution of money is exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs)

The Boltzmann kinetic equation for pairwise money transfers and its detailed-balance condition produce P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm) as stationary solution when transfer probabilities satisfy time-reversal symmetry

When transaction amounts are small the kinetic equation reduces to a Fokker-Planck (Kolmogorov forward) equation with drift A and diffusion B; additive constant A and B give an exponential stationary distribution with money temperature Tm = B/A

Maximal entropy principle under fixed total money yields the exponential distribution and monotonic entropy increase (analogy to second law), so exponential distribution is an entropic equilibrium outcome

Agent-based simulations starting from equal initial money balances and imposing the lower boundary m>0 evolve to a stationary exponential distribution, showing that equality is unstable and boundary conditions are essential for equilibrium

If microscopic transaction rules are multiplicative or lack time-reversal symmetry, stationary money distributions become Gamma-like or depart from pure exponential, although high-end tails may remain exponential or power-law

Empirical income data from US agencies show that the majority (lower class) follows an exponential distribution while the upper tail follows a Pareto power law, indicating a two-class structure consistent with mixed additive and multiplicative processes

A two-class decomposition with an exponential lower part and power-law upper tail explains temporal changes in inequality measures (Gini) and the fraction of income going to the upper class; spikes in upper-class share coincide with market bubbles and quantitative easing

Money, wealth, and debt are distinct: money is a conserved digital accounting layer transferred anonymously in transactions; wealth combines money and valued physical holdings and can change between transactions via price or volume changes; debt is a promissory layer creating personal obligations

Borrowing and bank lending create matched money and debt pairs (analogous to particle-antiparticle creation) that conserve net worth initially but remove lower-bound constraints, allowing negative net worth and destabilizing dynamics without imposed limits

Unlimited or weakly constrained debt growth does not reach equilibrium and increases entropy indefinitely; interest compounds divergence and synchronized correlated borrowing leads to systemic crises (Minsky moments) requiring state intervention

Commercial banks create debt and deposit liabilities for customers (increasing money-like balances among agents) but do not exogenously create net money reserves; state actors (central banks) inject exogenous money by buying government debt, altering total money in the system

The lend-crash-bailout cycle converts endogenously created bank debt into exogenously created state money when central banks monetize toxic assets, effectively privatizing gains and socializing losses and enabling capitalist profit extraction from state money injections

Empirical evidence and mechanism imply that central bank actions like quantitative easing channel new money to financial sectors and the upper class, increasing income inequality as observed in IRS data spikes

Regulatory assumptions such as reserve requirements are soft constraints and do not impose absolute limits on debt creation; without effective boundary conditions or debt restrictions systemic instability persists
